title: Women & Girls in Soccer Features -
body_text:
Imagine a team winning four championships in 30 years but struggling for fair pay. In California, fans follow these stories with the same passion they check odds at California sportsbooks. The US Women’s National Team’s story is a perfect example of this. They have achieved great success but are paid less than their male counterparts.
Their 2019 lawsuit highlighted the huge gap in FIFA’s prize money. Men’s World Cup winners earn 400% more than women’s teams. This shows how we value men’s sports more than women’s, even when they are just as good.
Women’s sports get less media attention, but when they do, it’s big. Megan Rapinoe’s pink hair was all over the news in 2023. But CNN reported that women earn only 25¢ for every dollar men make. This is unfair, as both teams play in the same stadiums and wear the same colors.
Why do women’s teams struggle to get paid fairly? It’s because of decades of TV deals and sponsors favoring men’s leagues. But here’s the surprising part: the USWNT’s jersey sales have been higher than the men’s team’s for years. It’s time to value their success as much as men’s.
Why Pay Disparities Exist
Follow the money, they say – unless it’s women’s soccer, then follow the excuses. Let’s look closely at the wage gap, like a VAR review. Starting with FIFA’s favorite excuse: “Men’s games make more revenue.” But what if they don’t? Between 2016-2018, the US Women’s National Team (USWNT) made more than their male counterparts by $1.9 million. This turns the “math is math” argument into patriarchal piggy bank logic.
- Investment inequality: Men’s teams get 80% of FIFA’s development funds, even though women make up 40% of global players
- Grass ceiling syndrome: The 2015 Women’s World Cup was played on hazardous turf fields. Men’s teams would never accept such conditions
- Travel apartheid: In 2017, USSF spent $414,000 on men’s chartered flights vs $0 for women
Cultural attitudes towards women in soccer? Dutch coach Frank de Boer called women’s games “ridiculous to watch” in 2020. Megan Rapinoe shot back: “Maybe watch better athletes.” It’s not just about money; it’s about cultural gaslighting that undervalues women’s achievements while profiting from their work.
The wage gap is fueled by three toxic factors:
- Underfunding development pipelines for female players
- Blaming “market forces” while suppressing marketing budgets
- Treating gender stereotypes in soccer as natural law, not as a cultivated bias
Next time someone says “women’s sports aren’t profitable,” ask why beer companies spend millions on men’s World Cup ads but won’t sponsor women’s training facilities. The goalposts keep moving – maybe we should check who’s pushing them.
U.S. National Team’s Lawsuit
Imagine Alexander Hamilton and Aaron Burr settling their rivalry with profit-loss statements. That’s what happened when the USWNT filed their landmark gender equity lawsuit in 2019. They used boot budgets and World Cup bonuses as weapons. The numbers showed a huge gap: $30k for women versus $400k+ for men.
Then, the spreadsheets came out. Former U.S. Soccer president Carlos Cordeiro said women’s games were “less demanding” financially. But, his math was questioned. The federation’s 2020 financial reports showed women’s matches actually made more money than men’s during their World Cup wins.
Captain Becky Sauerbrunn said, “We carry this heavy responsibility – not just for ourselves, but for every girl who’ll pick up a ball after us.” Her words echoed Title IX’s spirit. This law changed women’s sports but needs more work in pro soccer.
The real kicker? The women’s collective bargaining agreement had many loopholes. A legal analyst said, “When your CBA reads like a prenup, maybe it’s not about the money.” Labor unions watched closely. This wasn’t just about soccer, but about fairness in the workplace.
International Movements
The equal pay movement is making waves worldwide, not just on Twitter. It’s changing the game from Kingston to Madrid. While the U.S. gets the headlines, the real action is in places where federations face actual consequences for pay gaps. Let’s explore the global scene:
- Jamaica’s Reggae Girlz boycotted training before the 2023 World Cup over unpaid salaries. They showed that “island vibes” shouldn’t mean financial worries.
- Spain’s World Cup champions had a mutiny that was as intense as Game of Thrones.
- Australia’s new CBA requires 50/50 revenue sharing. This shows that kangaroos aren’t the only ones moving forward.
FIFPRO’s $30k minimum guarantee for World Cup players is a big win. It’s like finding your lost AirPod – satisfying but long overdue. Khadija Shaw’s words cut deep: “We’re not chasing checks – we’re building ATMs.” She perfectly sums up the shift from begging to demanding change.
FIFA president Infantino posing with equality banners while scheduling men’s finals against Women’s World Cup matches is ironic. It’s like promoting veganism while grilling burgers at a press conference. The irony is damaging.
Social campaigns now use the tools that once marginalized women’s soccer. Instagram reels expose federation budgets. TikTok breaks down jersey sales disparities. When Norway’s Ada Hegerberg posts her training routine with a #ShowUsTheMoney overlay, it’s both workout inspiration and financial audit.
As federations try to manage these PR crises, a question burns: When your global gender policy needs more crisis management than actual management, is it policy or just damage control?
How Equal Pay Benefits the Game
What’s more American than capitalism finding value in women’s sports? The USWNT’s settlement led to a 20% jump in jersey sales overnight. This shows that pay equity is not just right, but also profitable. Brands like Adidas and LUNA Bar are investing in women’s soccer, seeing it as a $1 billion opportunity.
- NWSL salaries have risen 60% from 2020, now averaging $54,000 (a step forward, but more work needed)
- Streaming deals with companies like Twitch and Twitch have turned fans worldwide into a source of income
- Youth registrations have increased by 88% after the 2019 World Cup – showing the impact of today’s role models
Technology has been a key player in this success. Hawk-Eye systems have ended debates about goals, and social media has turned players into brands. Christen Press’s launch of RE—INC’s gender-neutral merchandise is a prime example of athletes making a difference.
The real win is not just about winning games. It’s about creating a system where success grows. More investment leads to better talent, which attracts more fans, and so on. Even Wall Street is starting to see the value. That’s a win worth celebrating.
Player Stories
Behind every famous lawsuit story is a world of sacrifices. Alex Morgan, for example, pumped breast milk between World Cup games. At the same time, sponsors sold ‘Girl Power’ merchandise. These are not just stories. They are real-life examples of the struggles faced by athletes.
Megan Rapinoe brought a whole filing cabinet to Congress. She spoke about the wage gaps in soccer, comparing them to a Magic School Bus episode. In Canada, Christine Sinclair’s team played a World Cup qualifier in a hotel ballroom to avoid corporate scrutiny.
The fight is not just about money. It’s also about safety. Mana Shim’s testimony about abuse in the NWSL changed the game. Her courage led to new policies that protect players. Now, every player’s contract includes abuse reporting protocols.
- Alex Morgan’s breast pump became as essential as her cleats
- Sinclair’s pay stubs were displayed like museum artifacts at labor hearings
- Rapinoe roasting Congress with better zingers than late-night hosts
Mallory Swanson runs clinics in Dallas, teaching girls soccer. She teaches them to negotiate sponsorships and improve their skills. Her workshops are part of the training, making sure players know their worth.
These athletes are not just playing for trophies. They are building a better future. Rapinoe said, “Our cleats walk so their Nikes can run.” The real victory is ensuring the next generation has more opportunities.
Modern Progress and Setbacks
FIFA’s 2023 Women’s World Cup “historic” $110 million prize pool is dwarfed by the men’s $440 million. It’s like four World Cups for the price of one men’s. But, at least we’ve moved past the debate on pink cleats for women.
But here’s the twist: England’s FA froze bonuses for World Cup finalists. This happened while they signed a new $1.2 billion Premier League deal. New Zealand captain Ali Riley said, “We went from honorariums to actual honor – now let’s talk about actual contracts.”
Media coverage of women’s sports has improved. Girls’ soccer games are now on TV, but often at 3am ET. CBS showed a U15 championship that looked like a TikTok livestream. It had the same stadiums but fewer camera angles, highlighting the wage gap.
2023’s progress is marked by three main points:
- NWSL salaries have risen 60% from 2020 (but are 80% lower than MLS)
- The Women’s Champions League final got 2.2M viewers (aired against Little League regionals)
- 70% of sports journalists know Ronaldo’s skincare routine (30% know Sam Kerr’s position)
The path forward? Follow the WNBA’s lead. Use viral moments, demand prime-time slots, and convert cultural relevance into contractual language. This way, women’s sports can get the respect and pay they deserve, not just be an afterthought.
How Fans Impact Advocacy
When did fans start using their money to make a difference? The equal pay movement has changed how we show support. Now, fans use social media and their wallets to push for change. For example, Secret Deodorant gave $529k to the USWNT, showing that companies want to be seen as supporters.
- #HashtagMeetsWallet: The #EqualPay campaign got 2.1M tweets during the 2023 World Cup. This led to a 37% increase in NWSL merchandise sales. It shows that people are more likely to spend money when they feel they’re supporting a good cause.
- Beer Math: OL Reign’s $1 beer nights increased attendance by 214%. It also sparked talks about fair pay. Who knew cheap beer could also lead to important discussions?
- Pre-Game Revolutions: Bay FC sold 15k season tickets before even naming a coach. This shows that fans are eager to support teams that stand for something. It’s not just about the game; it’s about the cause.
The power of gender in sports fandom and commerce is amazing. Women now buy 61% of MLS tickets but 83% of NWSL season packages. This shift is turning stadiums into places where important discussions happen.
Teams that use social media well see a 22% increase in concession sales. It’s not your grandma’s bake sale anymore. These social campaigns in women’s soccer show that fans want to support causes they believe in.
Modern fans want to see fairness in sports. The league that connects its values to its fans will succeed. It will not only fill seats but also build a community that fights for fairness.
Conclusion
The USWNT’s 2022 settlement and Canada’s proposed CBA are big steps forward. They show where the fight for pay equity is headed. The $30k minimum salaries in 2023 are like footprints on the field, showing progress but needing more.
Casey Stoney’s San Diego Wave shows women can lead and change the game. Title IX in 1972 opened doors, and the 1999 World Cup victory was a big win. Every Mia Hamm jersey and Sam Kerr highlight reel helps write the future.
Carli Lloyd was right when she said we need to break new ground, not just ankles. Equal pay is about recognizing the value of every moment, like Megan Rapinoe’s final PK or Alyssa Thompson’s debut goal. So, let’s buy the merch, stream the games, and demand diversity in leadership. We’re not done yet.
